p: The Moscow region has faced significant climate changes over the past decades. Regional climate warming is now most pronounced since the 1970s, and is especially pronounced in the summer ( Figure 2a,b). Between 1977 and 2016, the average rate of growth of the mean summer temperature (June–August) was 0.6 °C per decade for rural areas [ 21]. The Moscow megacity forms an intensive urban heat island [ 22], which manifests itself as a mesoscale temperature anomaly that covers the whole city and even its neighboring regions [ 21, 23]. The urban–rural temperature contrasts could reach up to 13 °C in favorable weather conditions, while the annual mean temperature difference between the city center and rural surroundings is about 2 °C [ 21, 24]. Urban growth in recent decades has resulted in the intensification of the urban heat island ( Figure 2b) and caused additional amplification of the climate warming rates for urban areas [ 21, 25].
